title: A New Role of NAP1L1 in Megakaryocytes and Human Platelets
background: Platelets are anucleate cells traditionally considered incapable of nuclear functions, yet they contain nuclear proteins. The functional roles of these proteins in platelets and their megakaryocyte precursors remain largely unexplored, particularly in the context of systemic inflammatory conditions like sepsis.
objective: To investigate the expression, interaction partners, and functional roles of nuclear assembly protein 1 like 1 (NAP1L1) in human platelets and CD34+-derived megakaryocytes, with specific focus on sepsis-related changes.
methods: RNA sequencing, co-immunoprecipitation, mass spectrometry, immunofluorescence microscopy, Western blotting, pyruvate dehydrogenase complex activity assays, NAP1L1 overexpression in megakaryocytes, and proplatelet formation assays.
results: NAP1L1 is expressed in platelets and megakaryocytes as multiple transcript variants and protein isoforms. NAP1L1 directly interacts with PDC-E2, a key mitochondrial enzyme. Sepsis increases NAP1L1 expression and PDH activity in platelets, while NAP1L1 overexpression in megakaryocytes reduces proplatelet formation and PDH activity under LPS stimulation.
conclusion: NAP1L1 performs non-nuclear functions in platelets and megakaryocytes, interacting with mitochondrial proteins to influence energy metabolism and thrombopoiesis, with differential regulation during sepsis that may contribute to sepsis-associated thrombocytopenia.

learning_notes.note: NAP1L1, traditionally a nuclear protein, is expressed in anucleate platelets and interacts with mitochondrial PDC-E2, demonstrating that nuclear proteins can perform alternative functions in specialized cells. This interaction was confirmed through co-immunoprecipitation and mass spectrometry with specific spectrum counts (p=0.0271).

During sepsis, platelets show significantly increased NAP1L1 mRNA (p=0.0001) and protein expression, along with 13-fold increased PDH complex activity, suggesting metabolic adaptation to inflammatory stress that contrasts with typical mitochondrial inhibition in other cell types during sepsis.

NAP1L1 overexpression in megakaryocytes significantly reduces proplatelet formation (p=0.0064 for NAP1L1 vs noTx), with synergistic reduction when combined with LPS treatment (p=<0.0001), indicating impaired thrombopoiesis that may contribute to sepsis-associated thrombocytopenia.

Multiple NAP1L1 transcript variants and protein isoforms (60, 53, and 37 kDa) were identified in platelets and megakaryocytes, with variant 5 lacking exons 3-4 that code for the dimerization domain, suggesting specialized functions beyond nucleosome assembly.

The study reveals opposite PDH complex activity regulation in platelets (increased) versus megakaryocytes (decreased) under septic conditions, highlighting cell-type specific metabolic responses to inflammation that could inform targeted therapeutic approaches.

LPS treatment increases NAP1L1-PDC-E2 interaction in megakaryocytes while decreasing PDH activity, suggesting NAP1L1 may function as a chaperone or compartmentalization factor that regulates mitochondrial enzyme availability and activity in inflammatory states.

The research demonstrates that megakaryocytes can be successfully transfected using liposome-based methods with in vitro transcribed mRNA, enabling genetic manipulation studies in platelet precursor cells despite the technical challenges of modifying anucleate platelets directly.
